qas.question: How were women protected in Sumerian society?
Whose code reveals a bit about the societal structure through Sumerian law?
Who was at the top of the power pyramid in Sumerian society?
How many strata existed in Sumerian society?
Who had higher status in other cultures that in Sumeria?
Who's code protected women above all others?
Who was able to remarry whenever they chose?

context: Though <b5_0>women<b5_0/> were protected by late Sumerian <a0_0>law<a0_0/> and were able to achieve a higher status in Sumer than in other contemporary civilizations, the culture was <a1_0>male<a1_0/>-dominated. The Code of <a2_0><b6_0>Ur-Nammu<b6_0/><a2_0/>, the oldest such codification yet discovered, dating to the Ur-III "Sumerian Renaissance", reveals a glimpse at societal structure in late Sumerian law. Beneath <a3_0>the lu-gal<a3_0/> ("great man" or king), all members of society belonged to one of <a4_0>two<a4_0/> basic strata: The "lu" or free person, and the slave (male, arad; female geme). The son of a lu was called a dumu-nita until he married. <b7_0>A woman<b7_0/> (munus) went from being a daughter (dumu-mi), to a wife (dam), then if she outlived her husband, a widow (numasu) and she could then remarry.
